title: Properties of Linear Functions
text: Linear functions preserve vector addition. For example, $$f{\left(x+y\right)}=f{\left(x\right)}+f{\left(y\right)}$$.

title: Properties of Linear Functions
text: Linear functions also must preserve scalar multiplication. For example, $$f(cx)=cf(x)$$ for a constant value c.

title: Linear Combinations
text: A function that preserves both vector addition and scalar multiplication is one that preserves linear combinations.

title: Checking Linearity
text: To check if a function is linear, input example vectors to check that linear combinations are preserved.

title: Simple Checking
text: The easiest vectors to input into the function to check for linearity are the elementary basis vectors $$e_1$$ ,..., $$e_n$$ or vectors with every component equal to $$1$$.

title: Checking Vector Addition
text: Does calculating $$f(\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}+f(\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$ give the same answer as $$f(\begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}$$?

title: Checking Scalar Multiplication
text: Does calculating $$f(\begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}$$ give the same answer as $$2f(\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$ with $$2$$ as the constant scalar multiple?
